data: Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo XVIII
F. Ferrara, Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo XVIII (Catania, 1829)
Inscribed statue base for Lucius Rubrius Proculus
Four lines of Latin text, centred on the stone and filling the face, slightly decreasing in size from line 1.

Large, plain, deeply cut letters. P is open, R and B are closed; some upright strokes (all letter I, some L and V) have a serif ascending upper right; plain interpuncts in lines 1 and 3; the numeral in line 3 is marked by a mid-bar.
Lettering and absence of filiation suggest a 2nd century CE date (Korhonen)
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Civico di Catania
Castelli, 1769, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio
Castelli, 1784, Siciliae et objacentium insularum veterum inscriptionum nova collectio prolegomenis et notis illustrata, et iterum cum emendationibus, & auctariis evulgata
Ferrara, 1829, Storia di Catania sino alla fine del secolo XVIII
Libertini, 1937, Il Castello Ursino e le raccolte artistiche comunali di Catania
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Wilson, 1990, Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
Mole Ventura, 1996, Catania in etÃ  imperiale

Epitaph of Caius Pompeius Felix and Scribonia Restituta
Three lines of Latin letters, decreasing in height, and seemingly centred on the plaque.
Broad, square letter modules, in a wide V-cut with basic serifs, and triangular interpuncts.
1st century CE (Korhonen, by lettering and (lack of) formula)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dellâ€™IdentitÃ  Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dellâ€™IdentitÃ  Siciliana; photo J. Prag 13.05.2016

1[---]aviae av [---]
2[---]GemÍ¡elius [---]
3[---]etÌ£ . Geme[li---]
Three even and equal lines of text, carefully set out, with vacats above and below.

Orsi attributed it to the Norman period, Ferrua (1989) suggested the Saracen period due to the name Taric, and Manganaro suggests Gothic, each lowering the date therefore, which seems to belong in late antiquity, perhaps later 6th century CE, or earlier 7th century CE, dated by indiction (14th).
Manganaro, 1993, Greco nei pagi e latino nelle cittÃ  della Sicilia romana tra I e VI sec. d.C.
Orsi, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichitÃ
Ferrua, 1982-1983, Le iscrizioni datate della Sicilia paleocristiana
Ferrua, 1989, Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia

Carrera reports five lines of Greek letters

Carrera prints lunate sigma (and can print standard four bar sigma, so lunate should be understood). However the use of Latin S in line 2 and Latin R in lines 4 and 5 are presumably typographic errors / transliterations?

Remains of four lines of an incomplete Greek text centred on the stone

Moderately regularly and deeply incised letters with pronounced terminal points but without substantial serifs. Broken bar Î‘, lunate Î£ and Î•. Occasional use of hederae between words. Line lower right may be remains of a supraline above a numeral, or else an ornate hedera.
Second half of 1st century CE or 2nd century CE

Part of a base with Greek inscription
parts of five lines are recorded, but with no indication of the relationship of the text to the preserved surface.
Lunate sigma and epsilon are indicated in Ferrara's transcription.
Presumably later Roman imperial in date.

The remains of one line of Greek letters, preceded by a plain cross (which may be a later addition), are preserved on the moulding at the base of the relief.

Slightly irregularly disposed letters, with a hedera between the first two words. In the text preserved by Gualtherus lunate epsilon, sigma and cursive omega are recorded, and interpuncts before the numerals.
Later 2nd century CE or first half of 3rd century CE

Christian funerary epitaph for Romanos(?) and Agathe
Ferrara records broken bar alpha throughout, as well as lunate epsilon and sigma, minuscule omega, and delta with extended apex.
As Ferrua notes, the formula of purchase is Christian, so to be dated in the fourth to sixth centuries CE.
